title: How to Use a Chronograph Watch

steps.title: Pick a chronograph watch that is easy to read.
steps.content: Pick a chronograph watch that is easy to read. Chronograph watches have many small features that can be difficult to see. Choose a watch with a clear face that showcases each sub-dial clearly. Make sure that the hands on your watch contrast the color of the watch face, making them easy to see. [1] X Research source Be sure to try on a watch before buying it to make sure that you can see the numbers on your wrist without having to bring it up to your face.

steps.title: Buy a watch that can time the duration you want it to.
steps.content: Buy a watch that can time the duration you want it to. Chronograph watches range in terms of how long their timer function operates. Be sure to choose a watch that you can use for the purposes you have in mind. Some watches can only time 30 minutes at a time, while others have the capacity to time up to 12 hours. For instance, if you want a chronograph watch to time your long walks or runs, choose a model that times at least 2-3 hours at a time.

steps.title: Opt for a watch that is water- and shock-resistant if you're active.
steps.content: Opt for a watch that is water- and shock-resistant if you're active. If you live an active lifestyle, choose a watch that will stand up to water, sweat, and intense movement. You should also make sure that chronograph buttons on the side of the watch are not sensitive enough to turn on or off unexpectedly while you are moving. Shop for watches that will be easy to operate while you are active. [2] X Research source If you are going to swim while wearing your watch, choose a model that is water-resistant up to 200 or 300 meters. Watches that are water-resistant up to 30 meters are usually just splash-resistant, and not appropriate for swimming.

steps.title: Watch the second hand while you time things.
steps.content: Watch the second hand while you time things. On chronograph watches, the second hand is a long, thin hand that travels on the main dial of the watch. It records each second while your watch's chronograph function is being operated. Look for this hand in motion as the signal that the timer function of your watch is in use. [3] X Research source Note that watches without a chronograph function will not have this hand.

steps.title: Observe the minutes sub-dial on the face of your watch.
steps.content: Observe the minutes sub-dial on the face of your watch. Locate the minutes sub-dial right side of your watch face, where it is found on most chronograph watches. This small circle records the minutes that elapse while your chronograph function is turned on. Note the position of the minutes hand on this sub-dial to see the time recorded. The minutes sub-dial may be marked with a 30 or 60 at the top part of the circle, depending on the model of watch you have.

steps.title: Look at the hours subdial if you are using the chronograph for a long period of time.
steps.content: Look at the hours subdial if you are using the chronograph for a long period of time. On most chronograph watches, the hours subdial if found on the left of the watch face. Look at this subdial to note the number of hours passed. This function is particularly useful if you are tracking long events like marathon races. Most chronograph watches record up to 12 hours.

steps.title: Press the start/stop button on the side of the watch.
steps.content: Press the start/stop button on the side of the watch. On most chronograph watches, the button on the top right side starts and stops the chronograph. Locate this button and press it to start the timer. Be sure to only press it once, as pressing it a second time will stop it. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Press the button again once you are done using the chronograph.
steps.content: Press the button again once you are done using the chronograph. Keep your finger on the top right button while you use the stopwatch function of your watch. When you are done, press the button firmly to stop the timer. Look at the chronograph hand to make sure that it has stopped moving. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Press the second button to reset the chronograph.
steps.content: Press the second button to reset the chronograph. On most chronograph watches, the bottom right button resets the chronograph when you are done using it. Once you have noted the time you recorded on your watch, press the button. The hands on the sub-dials of your watch should return to their starting position. [6] X Research source The chronograph should be reset after every use, otherwise it will continue measuring time from the point you stopped it the next time you use it.

steps.title: Wind your watch if it is not automatic model.
steps.content: Wind your watch if it is not automatic model. Mechanical chronograph watches must be wound every day or two to keep them functioning. Take off your watch and hold it with the face towards you. Brace the crown of the watch and turn it clockwise repeatedly until you meet resistance. If your watch is completely run down, it may take 20-30 turns to wind it fully. [7] X Research source The crown is the small dial on the side of your watch. On most chronograph watches, the crown will be found on the right side under the start/stop button.
